prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3- lo
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: SiO 2-1 CCH N= 1-0, J = 3/2-1/2 CS 2-1 H40-alpha HCN 1-0 HCO+ 1-0

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity:
Based on our many previous centimeter wave observations of the NTFs at high spatial resolution, and assuming a flat spectrum, we expect the continuum emission at Band 3 to be approximately 1-2 mJy/1.5" beam. The thermal emission from the Sickle HII region is similarly strong. Therefore, with a required mosaic sensitivity of 0.06 mJy/1.5" beam in 1.34 hours, we will be imaging the continuum emission with a signal to noise of at least 20 which is especially important to be able to detect the faintest parts of the NTFs.
Based on our previous OVRO and more recent CARMA observations of CS (2-1) in the 25 km/s cloud (see Figure 1 (right)), we expect line intensities for similarly abundant species (HCN, HCO+) of 10s of mJy/1.5" beam (up to 100s of mJy/1.5" beam for bright lines of 13CO) for channel widths of up to 10 km/s, sufficient to minimally resolve the lines. The line sensitivity of our observations (4-5 mJy/1.5" beam) will allow us to detect CS (2-1) emission with a signal to noise of 7-10 and we can further smooth the data to image fainter features.
Imaging:
We propose to image a portion of the 25 km/s molecular cloud that underlies the Sickle HII region and also sample a reasonable length of the NTFs for the continuum study (approximate size is 2.5' x 2.5'). This region covers a large part of the cloud that is presumably physically interacting with the linear NTFs (at least they are observed to be intersecting in projection). The region is shown in Figure 2 (left) in the bright pink color. We request a spatial resolution of 1.5" in order to maximize the opportunity to observe high frequency substructure in the magnetic fields and in the molecular clouds, and to track any changes in spectral index when combined with the Band 6 observations of a portion of this region. In addition, the 1.5" resolution nicely matches our recent VLA K and Ka band study of the continuum and spectral lines in these molecular clouds (Lang, Mills, Butterfield, Morris et al., in prep.
Correlator Setup:
This particular set up we call "Band 3-lo" because it samples the lower end of Band 3 (85.8-89.5 and 97.7-101.5 GHz). The species that we are targeting for making images of the molecular gas in the two different clouds are: SiO (2-1), CCH (1-0) and (3/2-1/2), CS (2-1), H40 alpha, HCN and HCO+.
For all setups, we have requested the widest bandwidth per spectral window possible. This is slightly less total bandwidth than we could achieve with a continuum setup, but it will allows us to simultaneously image a number of important lines that are crucial to our understanding of the physical interaction of the gas and the magnetic NTFs at very high spatial resolution.

Sensitivity:
Based on our many previous centimeter wave observations of the NTFs at high spatial resolution, and assuming a flat spectrum, we expect the continuum emission at Band 6 to be approximately 1-2 mJy/1.5" beam. The thermal emission from the Sickle HII region is similarly strong. Therefore, with a required mosaic sensitivity of 0.06 mJy/1.5" beam in 2.14 hours, we will be imaging the continuum emission with a signal to noise of at least 20 which is especially important to be able to detect the faintest parts of the NTFs.
Based on our previous OVRO and more recent CARMA observations of CS (2-1) in the 25 km/s cloud (see Figure 1 (right)), we expect line intensities for similarly abundant species (HCN, HCO+) of 10s of mJy/1.5" beam (up to 100s of mJy/1.5" beam for bright lines of 13CO) for channel widths of up to 10 km/s, sufficient to minimally resolve the lines. The line sensitivity of our observations (4-5 mJy/1.5" beam) will allow us to detect CS (2-1) emission with a signal to noise of 7-10 and we can further smooth the data to image fainter features.
Imaging:
We propose to image a focused portion of the 25 km/s molecular cloud that includes the NTFs for the continuum study (approximate size is 0.5' x 2.5'). The region is shown in Figure 2 (left) in the bright cyan color. We request a spatial resolution of 1.5" in order to maximize the opportunity to observe high frequency substructure in the magnetic fields and in the molecular clouds, and to track any changes in spectral index when combined with the Band 3 observations of a portion of this region. In addition, the 1.5" resolution nicely matches our recent VLA K and Ka band study of the continuum and spectral lines in these molecular clouds (Lang, Mills, Butterfield, Morris et al., in prep.
Correlator Setup:
This particular set up we call "Band 6-lo" because it samples the lower end of Band 6 (216.8-220.9 and 232.6-236.6 GHz). The species that we are targeting for making images of the molecular gas in the two different clouds are: 13CO (2-1), 18CO (2-1), CO+, SiO and SO.
For all setups, we have requested the widest bandwidth per spectral window possible. This is slightly less total bandwidth than we could achieve with a continuum setup, but it will allows us to simultaneously image a number of important lines that are crucial to our understanding of the physical interaction of the gas and the magnetic NTFs at very high spatial resolution.

Sensitivity:
Based on our many previous centimeter wave observations of the NTFs at high spatial resolution, and assuming a flat spectrum, we expect the continuum emission at Band 3 to be approximately 1-2 mJy/1.5" beam. The thermal emission from the Sickle HII region is similarly strong. Therefore, with a required mosaic sensitivity of 0.06 mJy/1.5" beam in 1.12 hours, we will be imaging the continuum emission with a signal to noise of at least 20 which is especially important to be able to detect the faintest parts of the NTFs.
Based on our previous OVRO and more recent CARMA observations of CS (2-1) in the 25 km/s cloud (see Figure 1 (right)), we expect line intensities for similarly abundant species (HCN, HCO+) of 10s of mJy/1.5" beam (up to 100s of mJy/1.5" beam for bright lines of 13CO) for channel widths of up to 10 km/s, sufficient to minimally resolve the lines. The line sensitivity of our observations (4-5 mJy/1.5" beam) will allow us to detect CS (2-1) emission with a signal to noise of 7-10 and we can further smooth the data to image fainter features.
Imaging:
We propose to image a portion of the 25 km/s molecular cloud that underlies the Sickle HII region and also sample a reasonable length of the NTFs for the continuum study (approximate size is 2.5' x 2.5'). This region covers a large part of the cloud that is presumably physically interacting with the linear NTFs (at least they are observed to be intersecting in projection). The region is shown in Figure 2 (left) in the bright pink color. We request a spatial resolution of 1.5" in order to maximize the opportunity to observe high frequency substructure in the magnetic fields and in the molecular clouds, and to track any changes in spectral index when combined with the Band 6 observations of a portion of this region. In addition, the 1.5" resolution nicely matches our recent VLA K and Ka band study of the continuum and spectral lines in these molecular clouds (Lang, Mills, Butterfield, Morris et al., in prep.
Correlator Setup:
This particular set up we call "Band 3-upper" because it samples the upper end of Band 3 (95.2-98.9 and 107.3-111 GHz). The species that we are targeting for making images of the molecular gas in the two different clouds are: 13 CO (1-0), C18 (1-0), SO and two transitions of CH3OH.
For all setups, we have requested the widest bandwidth per spectral window possible. This is slightly less total bandwidth than we could achieve with a continuum setup, but it will allows us to simultaneously image a number of important lines that are crucial to our understanding of the physical interaction of the gas and the magnetic NTFs at very high spatial resolution.

Sensitivity:
Based on comparisons between G0.10-0.08 and the 25 km/s cloud, based on our previous OVRO and more recent CARMA observations of CS (2-1) in the 25 km/s cloud (see Figure 1 (right)), we expect line intensities for similarly abundant species (HCN, HCO+) to be 10s of mJy/1.5" beam (up to 100s of mJy/1.5" beam for bright lines of 13CO) for channel widths of up to 10 km/s, sufficient to minimally resolve the lines. The line sensitivity of our observations (4-5 mJy/1.5" beam) will allow us to detect CS (2-1) emission with a signal to noise of 7-10 and we can further smooth the data to image fainter features.
Imaging:
We propose to image the majority of the G0.10-0.08 cloud (approximate size is 1.75' x 1.75'). The region is shown in Figure 2 (left) in the bright pink color. We request a spatial resolution of 1.5" in order to maximize the opportunity to observe high frequency substructure in the molecular line emission, and potentially in the HCO+ absorption if there is any in this cloud. In addition, the 1.5" resolution nicely matches our recent VLA K and Ka band study of the continuum and spectral lines in these molecular clouds (Lang, Mills, Butterfield, Morris et al., in prep.
Correlator Setup:
This particular set up we call "Band 3-upper" because it samples the upper end of Band 3 (95.2-98.9 and 107.3-111 GHz). The species that we are targeting for making images of the molecular gas in the two different clouds are: 13 CO (1-0), C18 (1-0), SO and two transitions of CH3OH.
For all setups, we have requested the widest bandwidth per spectral window possible. This is slightly less total bandwidth than we could achieve with a continuum setup, but it will allows us to simultaneously image a number of important lines that are crucial to our understanding of the physical interaction of the gas and the magnetic NTFs at very high spatial resolution.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: MC: Band 3-lo
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: SiO 2-1 CCH N= 1-0, J = 3/2-1/2 CS 2-1 H40-alpha HCN 1-0 HCO+ 1-0

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity:
Based on comparisons between G0.10-0.08 and the 25 km/s cloud, based on our previous OVRO and more recent CARMA observations of CS (2-1) in the 25 km/s cloud (see Figure 1 (right)), we expect line intensities for similarly abundant species (HCN, HCO+) to be 10s of mJy/1.5" beam (up to 100s of mJy/1.5" beam for bright lines of 13CO) for channel widths of up to 10 km/s, sufficient to minimally resolve the lines. The line sensitivity of our observations (4-5 mJy/1.5" beam) will allow us to detect CS (2-1) emission with a signal to noise of 7-10 and we can further smooth the data to image fainter features.
Imaging:
We propose to image the majority of the G0.10-0.08 cloud (approximate size is 1.75' x 1.75'). The region is shown in Figure 2 (left) in the bright pink color. We request a spatial resolution of 1.5" in order to maximize the opportunity to observe high frequency substructure in the molecular line emission, and potentially in the HCO+ absorption if there is any in this cloud. In addition, the 1.5" resolution nicely matches our recent VLA K and Ka band study of the continuum and spectral lines in these molecular clouds (Lang, Mills, Butterfield, Morris et al., in prep.
Correlator Setup:
This particular set up we call "Band 3-lo" because it samples the lower end of Band 3 (85.8-89.5 and 97.7-101.5 GHz). The species that we are targeting for making images of the molecular gas in the two different clouds are: SiO (2-1), CCH (1-0; 3/2-1/2), CS (2-1), H40alpha, HCN and HCO+.
For all setups, we have requested the widest bandwidth per spectral window possible. This is slightly less total bandwidth than we could achieve with a continuum setup, but it will allows us to simultaneously image a number of important lines that are crucial to our understanding of the physical interaction of the gas and the magnetic NTFs at very high spatial resolution.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a multifrequency ALMA study of two Galactic Center molecular clouds that are believed to be physically interacting with the well-organized magnetic field in this region. The NTFs in the famous Radio Arc have long been known in the centimeter part of the spectrum, yet their shorter wavelength properties are not well-characterized and their origin remains a mystery. One scenario for the origin and acceleration of relativistic particles relies on the physical interaction of the Radio Arc NTFs, the Sickle HII region and the 25 km/s molecular cloud as well as another molecular cloud known as G0.10-0.08. Therefore, we focus on observing a region that includes these sources. Our scientific goals include: (1) characterizing the millimeter spectrum of the NTFs, which includes searching for a possible turnover frequency, and seeking spectral index changes along the NTF lengths, (2) making detailed images of the distribution and kinematics of molecular gas in two clouds where it intersects and aparently interacts with the NTFs, and (3) searching for possible magnetically-organized HCO+ absorption filaments.
